title: Craft assistant
jobRoles: These titles sometimes include direct reference to the specific craft that the ca is working in

knowledges.detail: The history of craft and how craft has shaped places, communities, and wider society
The history of your chosen craft
The economic contribution of craft and the make-up of the craft workforce
The different types of craft businesses including sole traders, publicly funded organisations, commercial operations, craft councils, associations and societies

The financial environmentof the craft sector and external factors impacting on this, and the ways in which craft practitioners and craft businesses generate income, such as through public/private subsidy, teaching, community outreach, product sales

The range of settings within which craft making is used to support the health, wellbeing and education of society e.g. in schools, hospitals, residential care homes, as part of community outreach projects, as well as the practical support craft practitioners can provide during a crisis e.g. the making of extra scrubs and face masks in the event of a pandemic

The environmental impact of different crafts and the steps being taken by craft practitioners and businesses to operate in a more environmentally sustainable way including circular economy concepts, sourcing of materials, sustainable production and distribution processes
The range and type of hand and machine operated tools used by craft makers and identify the craft/s and/or materials they are typically used for
The project life cycle and factors that aid successful progression including customer/client liaison, team working, budget management, project mapping and problem solving
The systems used to record and manage stock
The range and type of suppliers used by your organisation and how to research and source suppliers for financial competitiveness, environmental sustainability, and quality
Know how to store tools, materials and products safely and appropriately
The key principles of excellent customer service
How digital tools and technology, such as 3D printing and computer aided design can improve productivity and delivery
The different routes to market, including galleries and exhibitions, craft markets, open studios, online platforms, physical shops, printed materials such as books and catalogues
The different communication channels and methods used to reach clients/customers, suppliers, and key stakeholders such as social media, press, specialist networking, open studios, web
The basic principles that apply to copyrighting and Intellectual Property and how to protect craft items from external exploitation
The quality assurance methods and associated stages deployed by your organisation prior to releasing hand-made items to market
Benefits of eco-friendly/recycled materials including different packing materials, their properties and associated environmental impact/s
The 2010 Equality Act, 1998 Human Rights Act and the 1998 Equality, and the Equality and Human Rights Employer Code of Conduct for equality.

Health & Safety; regulations including the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH), Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations (PUWER), the Health & Safety At Work Act (HASAWA), the Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations (RIDDOR), and manual handling.
Key factors associated with ceramic items such as use and function, size, shape, ergonomics, fitness for purpose, and production scale

The types of clay used to make ceramic items, the unique properties of each, and the types of items each is most suitable for, including white earthenware, red/iron terracotta earthenware, stoneware, porcelain, bone china, fine bone china, magnesium clay
Characteristics and states of clay for industrial or studio production including slip, wet clay, leather hard, bone dry, bisque fired, glaze fired, post firing techniques, vitrified
Preparation methods of clay for use including wedging, kneading, pugging and filter pressing
Different making/production techniques including throwing, slab work, coiling, press moulding, slip casting, jigger and jollying, ram pressing, high pressure casting,
Different ways that decoration can be applied to ceramic items including stamping / embossing, sprig work, brushwork, decals, glaze and sgraffito

Different kiln and firing types including electric kiln, gas fired kilns, and wood/coal fired reduction firing, the use of different temperatures and the effect of different temperatures, and the stages of firing including bisque and glaze firings

The range, types and properties of different glazes and which one/s to use for the type of clay and the specific item being made, knowing when to use pigments and underglazes, biaxal and triaxal glazes, and glaze ‘recipes’
The different production processes and uses for ceramic products including personal use items, bespoke commissions, batch production, limited run, and mass production
Design principles including line, texture, size, shape, form, colour, volume, proportion

behaviours.detail: Committed to keeping up to date with industry best practice
Works effectively with colleagues and others
Sources solutions and seeks to continuously improve and develop
Puts safety first for themselves and others
Work in a time and budget conscious way

skills.detail: Select and safely use the most appropriate tools for your chosen craft
Use technology as an enabler to make hand-crafted items, models and prototypes
Use green production techniques, processes and recycled materials to deliver hand-crafted items
Store tools/materials safely and appropriately, ensuring they are protected from damage when not in use
Follow the appropriate Health & Safety procedures for your chosen craft, using tools, materials and personal protective equipment ( PPE) in a safe and secure way
Clean, maintain and prepare the craft workspace/workshop in line with the organisation’s requirements, contributing to a safe and heathy working environment
Identify the roles, responsibilities, and interdependencies of different parties in a project and your role within this
Undertake budget setting and deploy controls to enable effective budget management
Undertake duties in line with project timelines, demonstrating the reputational, financial, and legal risks of not completing a project to time or budget
Demonstrate effective stock control and supplier liaison
Demonstrate effective verbal and written communication with colleagues, and/or customers/clients, and suppliers in line with the organisation’s expectations
Follow the organisation’s quality assurance procedures
Choose the most appropriate packaging for your craft items to protect them whilst in transit and to ensure items are presented as per the organisation’s and/or client/customer requirements

Make ceramic items and/or prototypes in line with the organisation’s brief / private client / customer brief / own brief, ensuring close consideration is given to its chosen purpose, end user, market, and budget

Select and use the most appropriate tools and equipment for the ceramic item/s being made such as a wheel, wire clay cutter, sponges, shapers, brushes, loop and ribbon tools, bats, calipers, glazing tongs, pugmill, filter press, blunder, extruder, kiln
Apply design principles in the making of ceramic items, relative to the brief including shape, size, proportion, colour and finish
Select the most appropriate clay for the ceramic item being made to ensure the final item is fit for purpose

Employ a range of relevant making skills such as hand building, sculpting, throwing, casting, moulding, and tool crafting ensuring these are appropriately selected and applied to the chosen clay relevant to the final product
Decide on decorative techniques and glazes to be applied to the final ceramic products
Evaluate the extent to which the finished ceramic item meets the detail of the brief and against the production schedule including efficiency and wastage, quality, budget
Use technical drawings (created by hand and/or digital) to aid the making of a hand-made ceramic product

involvedEmployers: Heritage Craft Association, Devon Guild of Craftsmen, 1882 Ltd, The Leach Pottery, Royal Crown Derby, Spode Museum, Creative and Cultural Skills
typicalJobTitles: These titles sometimes include direct reference to the specific craft that the ca is working in
englishAndMathsQualifications: Apprentices without level 2 English and maths will need to achieve this level prior to taking the End-Point Assessment. For those with an education, health and care plan or a legacy statement, the apprenticeship’s English and maths minimum requirement is Entry Level 3. A British Sign Language (BSL) qualification is an alternative to the English qualification for those whose primary language is BSL.
reviewDetails: This apprenticeship standard will be reviewed after three years

duties.dutyDetail: Utilise technology as an enabler to make hand crafted items within the social, cultural, economic, technological and environmental contexts impacting craft
Make products or component parts of products by hand in line with the organisation’s quality standards, confidentiality policies and Intellectual Property requirements
Focus on sustainability, research and develop green production techniques, processes and the use of recycled materials
Maintain equipment and the workspace, and store tools in line with the organisation’s standards and Health and Safety requirements
Record and control materials, items, stock, products and suitably store these to maintain their fitness for use
Order or recommend materials and/or tools in line with the organisation’s procurement policies/processes and stock management procedures as needed to achieve value for money
Follow agreed plans, designs or brief to aid the successful creation of a specified hand-made product within time and cost constraints
Manage client expectations by maintaining regular client communication and delivering effective project management, budget tracking, troubleshooting, project delivery and timekeeping
Utilise technology to communicate, market and sell hand-made items effectively
Provide excellent and inclusive customer service and relationship management to a diverse range of clients
Package/present products in line with the organisation’s standards, procedures and/or client/customer requirements
Make, service, restore, and/or conserve ceramic items for customers/clients and/or public/private collections
Manage the planning and/or design process for hand-made ceramic products
Work with clients/customers to understand their requirements and creating technical and/or other drawings and plans (by hand or digital) for the product as needed
Create samples and/or prototypes to assist in the creation of hand-made ceramic products
